review.title: OBTAIN: Real-Time Beat Tracking in Audio Signals
review.abstract: In this paper, we design a system in order to perform the real-time beat tracking for an audio signal. We use Onset Strength Signal (OSS) to detect the onsets and estimate the tempos. Then, we form Cumulative Beat Strength Signal (CBSS) by taking advantage of OSS and estimated tempos. Next, we perform peak detection by extracting the periodic sequence of beats among all CBSS peaks. In simulations, we can see that our proposed algorithm, Online Beat TrAckINg (OBTAIN), outperforms state-of-art results in terms of prediction accuracy while maintaining comparable and practical computational complexity. The real-time performance is tractable visually as illustrated in the simulations.

INTRODUCTIONMany studies have been done in offline beat tracking, and effective algorithms can be found in the literature that perform beat tracking offline [1]. These methods have access to all signal data. However, in this paper we propose a new algorithm for real-time beat tracking. Beat Tracking is a tool for processing audio signals based on insertion detection. Onset detection is an important topic in signal processing. It can be observed in various parts of research that insertion signals are processed, such as music signal processing [2], neural signal processing (EEG, ECoG, and FMRI), and other biomedical signal processing areas such as electrocardial signals, to name a few.

sections.heading: B. Tempo Estimation
sections.text: We store the OSS we received in the previous phase in a buffer of the length of 256. Each buffer contains 256 OSS signals. Two intuitive reasons behind this choice of the length for the buffer could be firstly the robustness of the real-time process, and secondly the time it takes for the buffer to load enough samples for detection would be about 3 seconds, which is roughly compatible with human hearing in beating detection. sections.heading: C. Cumulative Beat Strength Signal (CBSS)
sections.text: We use a method similar to the one introduced in [8]. To create CBSS for each frame, we first search for the previous beat that is considered to be the peak in that signal. CBSS for a frame corresponds to the weighted sum of OSS in the corresponding frame and the value of the CBSS of the last beat using different weights. Now, we explain how to find the last beat. To this end, we use a Log-Gaussian window. To determine the position of the beats, we use a recursive method to assign a score to each time window that determines the impact force in the workframe. The maximum value among these scores indicates the beat locations. CBSS is achieved by calculating the sum of two beats: one from the previous frames and the other from the current frame. Let us determine the estimated beat period from the tempo estimate.

sections.heading: D. Beat Detection
sections.text: In this section, periodic peaks of the CBSS concept are recorded in real time, and the "beatDetected" output signal is a flag that is set to 1 when a peak is detected in that frame. This block uses two separate parallel systems to increase the reliability of system performance; the initial system simply keeps track of periodic beats without regard to the beat period, while the second system is entirely dependent on the beat period; the main assumption is that if the beat period is not detected correctly, the cumulative signal still maintains its periodic pattern; hence, the second system is a correction system based on comparing the CBSS values at the peak positions of these two systems; the system produces higher averages; each frame consisting of 512 samples of the CBSS system is fed into a buffer; two consecutive buffers are overlapped with 511 common samples (similar to the FIO concept).

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we propose an algorithm for real-time beat tracking (OBTAIN). We use OSS to detect intrusions and estimate tempo. We then form a CBSS by using OSS and tempo. Next, we perform peak detection by extracting the periodic sequence of beats between all CBSS peaks. Simulation results provide better results compared to the IBT method. The algorithm exceeds current results in terms of predictions while maintaining comparable and practical computational complexity. Real-time performance is comprehensible.
